column1: The weather since the last sampling of 2009 needs mention.  The weather alternated monthly.  We set many records.  September was the fourth hottest on record- and dry.  We had 5? of rain from October 1-8.  There were snowfalls of about two inches on both October 9 and 11: this was only the third time in 40 years that two measureable snowfalls occurred this early in October.  Overall- October was the second wettest an fourth coldest in history.  November was the second warmest in history.  Only one day was at or below the normal daytime/nighttime temperature.  It was also extremely dry.  Only about 0.5 inches of snow- on the last day of deer hunting: November 29.  The average snowfall in November is about 5?.  December 1-3 temperatures were above the normal daytime/nighttime high/low.  Beginning with December 4- we were below normal.  Some of the November 29 snow is still visible.  Just before Christmas we had about 12 inches of snow.  Unfortunately- it was intermingled with rain and freezing rain.  As a result- there is water on the ice under the snow- making it impossible to navigate- either on foot or by motorized vehicle.  January 1 through January 10- 2010- we had only had one day that was ?normal?.  Otherwise- we had an extended cold snap (well below zero most nights- with single digit highs).  As a result- our lakes were now navigable: the water previously covering the ice apparently absorbed the snow before freezing up.  There was now about 2? of snow on top of good ice.  February was colder than normal- and dry.  March was very warm.  April was the warmest on record.  The ?meteorological spring?- (March and April) was the warmest on record.  March had zero measurable snowfall: a first since records were kept in 1884.  Unofficial Reports from the 1860s (probably from army forts) report one such year that matched this event.  On May 7- we had measurable snow.  On May 20- we had 95 degrees- which eclipsed the previous high for that date by 8 degrees.

On July 1- we had a terrific thunderstorm.  One hundred plus MPH winds with downdrafts- causing pockets of extreme damage.  Overall- the storm leveled 20-000 acres of timber in Burnett County.  It affected an area about 50 miles to south x 75 miles- east to west- including other counties- and some in Minnesota (e.g. St. Croix State Park was severely damaged).  This does not include the hundred of individual property owners that encountered severe damage to trees- buildings- vehicles- campers- etc.
It was Friday- the beginning of the 4th of July holiday- so many visitors were in the area.  Many of their vehicles/campers were damaged- or destroyed.
It was also the weekend of festivities commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Siren tornado.

That Friday the daytime temperature reached 97 degrees : then a cold front approached.  NOAA radio warned of the storm- indicating the storm itself was travelling west to east at 65 MPH.  Damaging wind and the possibility of hail were included: those in the path and listeners were told to seek cover immediately.

At 8 PM a cold front moved in and a severe thunderstorm hit- with winds of 100 MPH and higher.  There were ?fingers/downdrafts/micro bursts? (pick your noun)- that caused the damage to be more severe in scattered pockets.  The storm itself moved at 65 MPH- so there was little advanced warning.  .  The lake looked almost like the biblical ?parting of the sea?.  Two more storms came through between then and 9:30- but none were severe.  The damage around the lake- including snapped power lines and blocked roads- is severe.  Many large trees are down: both snapped off and uprooted.  Some damage to vehicles and campers in for the 4th of July weekend.  Traffic coming in for the weekend was backed up a long distance between Hayden Lake Road and Highway 35.  Headlights illuminated the night as locals and travelers with chain saws cleared the road just north of the bridge to Falk Lake.

Stories spread quickly as people came to the roads serving the cabins.  On our Minerva Circle- two visitors- one an 89 year old man were in tent campers that had trees fall on them: both narrowly escaped.  One had the tree between him and the door- and could not get out for quite some time.

Local gas stations brought in the huge rented generators within a day- so pumps were functional.  However- it was cash only- with no change available once the first customers emptied the tills.  And the banks were not open to withdraw funds.  The local grocer was not open- but had semis come in with truckloads of ice

Most residents were without power for a week- and several for over two weeks.  Power companies from adjacent counties- including some in MN- and even a city in southern WI came forward to assist.  The main reason for the extreme time to restore power- besides the huge task of tree removal- was that countess power poles were snapped off- which led to the logistical problem of locating replacement poles- and then clearing areas to gain access and replace them.
The loss of power- plus theurn of extreme heat- caused  many visitors to return home- and made the tedious job of clean up even more exhausting.

This July is the fourth hottest in history.  We have had twelve days of 90 degrees  and above- and several more above 85 degrees .  There was an historical high dew point of 82 degrees .  Several days had heat indices over 100 degrees .

column1: Much background is needed to set a baseline for this lake sampling season.

March blew away the temperature record from 1910.  The Average high was 15 degrees above normal.  From March 10 to the 21st- 10 of the 12 days set new records.  Typical highs during this time are in the 40s: all the highs were about 30 degrees  above normal.  That not only blew away the previous March record- it set a record as the greatest number of degrees above normal for any month in recorded history.

Understandably- the ice on our lakes went out very early: Cranberry on March 22 and Minerva on March 23.  A typical ice out date is April 6.  Last year- with the snowy- cold winter- ice out was April 20.  Since the beginning of our "meteorological spring" (March- April- and May) was preceded by a winter quarter (summarized below) of very warm readings- the early ice out is expected.

The "Meteorological Winter"- from December 2011 through February 2012 continued as an unusual weather year.  The average snowfall for this period is 28": we have had about 14" (last year during this period we had over 40").  The average number of below zero readings in this period is about 20: we have had 3.  This is the second fewest on record: the record is 2 (I believe set in 2002).  As of 2/9/2012 our average temperature was 26.7 degrees  for this winter period.  This is the fourth warmest in history: the previous record temperature to this date- 1877-1878 was 29 degrees .  Interestingly- 1930-31 is in second place and 2001-2002 in third

Ice over occurred on December 2- 2011- on both Minerva and Cranberry lakes.  This compares to November 25 of last year- which is more typical date.  Ice fishing on foot was possible by mid December.  It was not until after January 1- 2012- that ATV traffic was safe.  Larger vehicle traffic was not safe until mid-late January. Thus- with the early March warm up- we effectively had about a five week ice fishing season.  And to top it off- the fishing was terrible.  The unusual weather meant many barometer swings- which the fish- being pressure sensitive- do not like: they have constant tummy aches.
Also- with the extreme lack of snow- snowmobile trails were not opened until mid February: basically wiping out the season.
Both of the above led to extreme hardship of many retailers depending on winter sports to carry them through the year.

On a related note- maple syrup producers were hardly able to collect enough sap- at 40:1 per gallon of syrup- to even begin the boiling.   February began warm- with some below freezing nights- so the sap began to flow.  Then as February turned to march- there were no more nights below freezing.  The taps need some continuity to continue to produce- so they dried up.  The normal number of productive days for the producers is thirty: this season there were six.

April has been a month of below normal temperatures.  We had measureable snow on April 15.  This is a godsend in some respects.  Since fish spawn at certain temperatures- the early spawners (e.g. Crappie) were nearly ready to spawn at the end of March.  If April had continued warm- the females would have deposited their eggs- probably before the eggs were mature- and we may have lost an entire year class of fish.  It also would have affected Perch and Walleye.

column1: Cranberry?s 2012 ice over occurred on December 5: Minerva?s December 10.  Beginning with these December dates- the temperatures were quite cold- so ice formed quickly before snow cover was a factor.  As winter progressed- the ice formed clear and hard.  When snows arrived- and began to pile up- the ice was firm- and relatively thick.  In late February- we received some rain- followed by very cold temperatures.  This dissolved some of the snow and formed a secondary ice cover above the base. Travel with an ATV was no longer an option: the tires would break through the secondary layer and have no traction on the ice below.  Walking was also difficult.  Even during this stage the solid ice was about 30? thick.  Then- March and April snows came- re-insulating the ice.  It became obvious ice out would be very late- unless rains or abnormally warm temperatures occurred: they did not.  In 2012- there were 90 degree temperatures in March and April!  This April- we probably set an all time record for April snow depth:  We had more than 30?.  Wisconsin?s fishing opener was May 5.   Cranberry was ice-free- but there was no way to reach it from the Falk landing: Minerva still had solid ice.
On February 8 + 9- The Minerva/Cranberry Lake Association placed 22 cribs on Minerva Lake: 10 on the upper lake and 12 on the lower.  All settled through the ice to the lake bottom by May 5.

This was a very nice July.  We only had 2 days with temps above 90 degrees- compared to last year?s 19!  And- there was sufficient rain until mid July.  Since then- the rain has been sparse: less than 1 inch.  Nationally and world-wide- this summer has been very hot.  The only cool pocket is in the Midwest.  One thing that is ever present is the wind: there are very few calm days.  Secchi readings are difficult under windy conditions.  And- on many days we could not do sampling or Secchi because the anchor could not hold the pontoon.  Until mid July- the lake was high: since- it has been normal- or low.  Perhaps they took a timber out of the dam.

It has been an unusual summer for bugs.  Because of the wet spring- the mosquitoes have been more numerous- especially during the bright hours of the day- when they are usually not active.  When out of the wind- they are around.

On the other hand- the deer flies- which usually come in the first two weeks of June and last through July- did not arrive until early July: we suppose that means they will last through August.  Likewise- there are fewer gnats than in the past.  Both may be because in mid-December of 2013 we had an 18 inch snowfall at around 32 degrees.  Then- the temperatures dropped to below zero- resulting in a thick coating of ice on the snow.  And- the snow continued to be frequent.  Officially- we had 155 inches of snow!  Smaller Evergreen trees (12 feet and under) were OK under the snow line- but above the snow line there was much browning: hopefully they will overcome it before the next winter season.

column1: Worldwide- 2015 was the hottest year on record.  It was 1.5  degrees Fahrenheit warmer than the previous record- which was 2014.  So- we had two record hot years in a row!

Ironically- it did not hold true for our area- and most of the Midwest.  We only had two days over 90 degrees and had about 40 inches of rain from April through mid October (we have a dial on our rain gage to manually register rainfall accumulation).
It was probably the nicest summer we can remember since we bought our place in 1993: moderate temperatures and ample rainfall.

Ironically- it was one of the windiest.  We take Secchi readings as often as possible (beside the readings we take in conjunction with the complete temperature profiles and chemical analysis in May- June- July- and August.  This year we only had two additional Secchi readings- one on 13 July and another on 16 August.  We are usually at the lake weekly from Friday PM through Tuesday AM- and had difficulty finding good daylight times.  When winds are strong- the pontoon cannot hold anchor.

column1: performed on July 4- 2016.  The min reasons the sampling delayed into July was the June 25th 6:30 PM windstorm that caused significant tree loss in the immediate vicinity of our residence (29667 Minerva Circle) and the properties north and south of us (on the west leg of Minerva Circle) We lost 15 trees- six of which were on the ?finished? portion of our lot.: the balance were in the wooded area between us an the neighbor to the south- and across Minerva circle from our lake site.  We and other neighbors cleared two trees that blocked the west leg.  Included in our loss were about 30 feet of the tops of 3 of the 75 foot Norway pines planted by the CCCs in the mid 1930s.

We believe the damage was as localized as it was because of a ?Microburst? occurring along with an approximate 60 MPH straight line wind- with gusts to 70 MPH.  A microburst is a downdraft that- when it hits the ground results in an ?explosion? of wind radiating in all directions.  The pines and an oak were felled by wind from the west (the main direction of the wind).  However- ten trees in the ?rough between us and the neighbor to the south fell to wind from the north- even though shielded by our high Gambrel-roofed garage.

This storm was 6 days shy of five years from the July 1st 2011 storm that flattened 110-000 acres of timber in MN and WI.  That one had 100 MPH winds from a wall cloud.  Everyone around the area was without power for at least a week- and some for as long as three weeks.  And the temps were in the high 80s most of that time.  Power companies from neighboring states and beyond were summoned to help restore power.  Power generators sold out in the twin ports and win cities immediately after the roads were cleared and folks could get out.
One that was behind us- we waited until July 4th to sample and do the lab work.  Otherwise- the shipment would sit is post offices until after the 4th anyway- and the iced samples would be suspect.

The shore temperature at the approximate 3 PM sampling time was 79 degrees- the wind west at about 10 MPH. We had 2 inches of rain during the June 25th storm- and ? inch since.  The chop made the secchi reading difficult on Cranberry Lake- but secchi on Minerva was not impaired.

As an aside- since this data is being entered on July 19th we had at least 10-1/2 inches of rain on Sunday night/Monday morning July 10/11.  This amount was reported by Steve and Peg Johnson on the south side of Minerva Lake.  They emptied their rain gage before bedtime with 4 inches of accumulation.  Monday morning- the 6 inch capacity rain gauge had overflowed.  All local rivers overflowed their banks.  Our lakes rose about a foot immediately following the storm.
